Also at \(x=1\) the series is convergent (alternating harmonic series) and at \(x=-1\) the series is divergent. Hence this Maclaurin expansion is only valid if \(1< x \leq 1\). The geometrical closeness of polynomial terms with function \(\ln (1+x)\) for \(-1<x\le 1\) is displayed in the figure below.


Linear, quadratic and cubic approximations to \(\ln (1+x)\)

Note that when \(x=1\) \(\ln 2=1-\dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{1}{3}-\dfrac{1}{4}\cdots\) so the alternating harmonic series converges to \(\ln 2\simeq 0.693\).

The Maclaurin expansion of a product of two functions: \(f(x)g(x)\) is obtained by multiplying together the Maclaurin expansions of \(f(x)\) and of \(g(x)\) and collecting like terms together. The product series will have a radius of convergence equal to the smaller of the two separate radii of convergence.
